title: Mt Hollywood Trail: Complete Hiking Guide to LA's Best Views 2024
description: I first discovered the Mt Hollywood trail three years ago during a particularly stressful period at work. What started as a desperate need for fresh air turned into my favorite weekly ritual. This 2.5-mile round trip hike from Griffith Observatory has become my go-to recommendation for anyone visiting Los Angeles, and for good reason.

body:
Mt Hollywood Trail: Complete Hiking Guide to LA's Best Views 2024

After hiking the Mt Hollywood trail over a dozen times in different seasons, I can confidently say this is Los Angeles' most rewarding short hike. This comprehensive guide shares my personal experiences, insider tips, and everything you need to know for an unforgettable adventure to one of LA's best viewpoints. Whether you're seeking Hollywood Sign views, downtown skylines, or a peaceful escape from city life, this trail delivers exceptional experiences year-round. Explore more national park adventures to discover your next hiking destination.

Table of Contents

1. My Personal Experience 2. Trail Overview & Getting There 3. What to Expect on the Hike 4. Essential Gear Recommendations 5. Best Times & Seasonal Tips 6. Safety Tips & Trail Etiquette 7. Conclusion

My Personal Experience on Mt Hollywood Trail

I first discovered the Mt Hollywood trail three years ago during a particularly stressful period at work. What started as a desperate need for fresh air turned into my favorite weekly ritual. This 2.5-mile round trip hike from Griffith Observatory has become my go-to recommendation for anyone visiting Los Angeles, and for good reason.

My most memorable experience happened last spring during wildflower season. I arrived at the Charlie Turner Trailhead just after sunrise, armed with my trusty AllTrails app and a determination to beat the crowds. The morning air was crisp, and as I began the ascent through Berlin Forest, the city's usual haze hadn't yet settled in. The trail was quiet except for the occasional hiker and their leashed dogsâ€”a reminder that this is one of LA's most dog-friendly hiking spots.

What struck me most was the gradual revelation of views. Unlike some trails that save the best for last, the Mt Hollywood trail offers increasingly spectacular vistas at every turn. About halfway up, I encountered a park ranger who shared invaluable local knowledge: "The secret," he told me, "is timing your hike for golden hour, either sunrise or sunset. That's when the city truly comes alive below you." His advice proved goldenâ€”literally.

Pro Tip from My Experience: The trail can get crowded after 10 AM on weekends, but weekday mornings offer a completely different experience. I've often had entire sections to myself, making it feel like a private escape from the bustling city below.

Trail Overview and Getting There

Trail Statistics

  • Distance: 2.5 miles round trip
  • Elevation Gain: 500 feet
  • Difficulty: Easy to Moderate
  • Duration: 1.5-2 hours
  • Dog-Friendly: Yes, on-leash

Parking Information

  • Main Lot: Griffith Observatory
  • Cost: $4-15 per hour
  • Free Options: Greek Theatre area
  • Best Times: Before 8 AM weekdays

The Mt Hollywood trail begins at the Charlie Turner Trailhead, located at the north end of the Griffith Observatory parking lot. This strategic starting point isn't coincidentalâ€”it positions you perfectly for post-hike exploration of one of LA's most iconic landmarks. I've learned through experience that parking can make or break your hiking day, especially on weekends.

During my early hiking attempts, I made the rookie mistake of arriving at the observatory around noon on a Saturday. After circling the parking lot three times, I finally found a spot but paid dearly for itâ€”both financially and in terms of stress. Now I always recommend the alternative approach: park near the Greek Theatre for free and extend your hike by about 0.5 miles each way. This route actually enhanced my experience, as I discovered additional trails that require proper footwear throughout Griffith Park.

From downtown LA, take the 5 Freeway to Los Feliz Boulevard, then follow signs to Griffith Observatory. The winding road up Western Canyon provides a scenic prelude to your hike, with glimpses of the trail system you'll soon be exploring. I particularly enjoy this approach in the early morning when the city is still waking up and the light filters beautifully through the canyon.

Experience the Mt Hollywood trail through this comprehensive hiking video guide

What to Expect on the Hike

The Mt Hollywood trail unfolds like a well-choreographed performance, with each section offering distinct experiences and challenges. After countless hikes on this trail, I've identified several key landmarks that serve as natural waypoints and rest stops.

Your journey begins with a gentle ascent through shaded tree coverageâ€”a blessing during summer months. The first major landmark is Berlin Forest, approximately 0.3 miles from the trailhead. This grove of pine trees was planted to commemorate the sister-city relationship between Los Angeles and Berlin. I've found this area particularly peaceful in early morning hours, when the filtered sunlight creates almost cathedral-like conditions. The benches here offer the first good views of the Hollywood Sign, perfectly framed by pine boughs.

Continuing past Berlin Forest, the trail opens up significantly, transforming from a woodland path to a wide fire road. This section provides consistent views and steady climbing. I appreciate how the Mt Hollywood trail maintains a manageable grade throughoutâ€”never so steep as to be discouraging, but challenging enough to provide a genuine workout. The improved hiking boots I invested in last year made a noticeable difference in comfort during this section.

The trail's halfway point presents a crucial decision: continue straight toward Dante's View or take the left fork toward Captain's Roost. Both destinations offer unique perspectives, but I typically recommend Dante's View for first-time hikers. This well-maintained rest area features picnic tables, a water fountain, and arguably the best panoramic views of downtown LA and the San Gabriel Mountains. The volunteers who maintain this area have created something truly specialâ€”it feels like a secret garden suspended above the city.

Trail Highlights You Won't Want to Miss:

  • Berlin Forest: Perfect Instagram spot with Hollywood Sign backdrop
  • Dante's View: Best panoramic city views and water fountain
  • Captain's Roost: Palm tree vista point ideal for sunset photos
  • Summit Views: 360-degree panorama including ocean on clear days

Essential Gear for Mt Hollywood Trail

After years of hiking the Mt Hollywood trail in various conditions and seasons, I've refined my gear recommendations to focus on items that truly enhance the experience. While this isn't a technically demanding trail, having the right equipment can mean the difference between an enjoyable outing and an uncomfortable slog.

Footwear

The trail's mixed terrainâ€”from smooth dirt paths to occasional rocky sectionsâ€”demands versatile footwear. I learned this lesson the hard way during my first hike in regular sneakers.

Men's Hiking Boots - $49.59

Amazon's Choice - Waterproof & Lightweight

Hydration

LA's dry climate and the trail's limited shade make proper hydration crucial. A hands-free hydration system allows you to drink regularly without stopping.

Hydration Backpack - $23.99

Amazon's Choice - 2L Capacity with Bladder

Trekking Poles

While not essential for this trail, I've found poles helpful for stability on descents and reducing knee strain, especially after long photography sessions at the summit.

Nordic Walking Poles - $21.23

Amazon's Choice - Anti-Shock & Telescopic

Beyond these essentials, I always pack sunscreen (LA's sun is deceivingly strong at elevation), a lightweight first-aid kit, and snacks for energy. The trail's popularity means cell service is generally excellent, but I still recommend downloading offline maps through apps like AllTrails as a backup.

For photography enthusiasts, the Mt Hollywood trail offers endless opportunities. I've found that a lightweight tripod significantly improves sunset and sunrise shots, particularly for capturing the city lights as they begin to twinkle in the early evening. The trail's various viewpoints accommodate different focal lengths, from wide-angle panoramas to telephoto shots of the Hollywood Sign.

Seasonal Gear Adjustments:

Summer: Extra water, wide-brimmed hat, cooling towel
Winter: Light jacket for summit winds, layers for temperature changes
Spring: Camera for wildflower photography, allergy medication if needed
Fall: Light layers for variable temperatures, extra time for golden hour photos

Best Times to Hike and Seasonal Tips

Timing can make or break your Mt Hollywood trail experience. After hiking this trail in every season and at virtually every time of day, I've developed strong opinions about when this trail truly shines. The magic hoursâ€”sunrise and sunsetâ€”transform this already spectacular hike into something transcendent.

My personal favorite time is the hour before sunrise on clear mornings, particularly during fall and winter months when the air is crisp and visibility extends to the Pacific Ocean. Starting in darkness with a headlamp might seem daunting, but watching the city wake up below you is unforgettable. I've witnessed dozens of sunrises from the summit, and each one feels like a private performance. The challenge lies in motivationâ€”few people are willing to start hiking at 5:30 AM, but those who do are rewarded with solitude and photographic opportunities impossible to achieve during peak hours.

Summer hiking requires careful planning due to LA's intense heat and sun exposure. The trail offers minimal shade beyond the initial tree cover, making early morning starts essential between June and September. I typically recommend beginning no later than 7 AM during summer months. However, summer evenings present magical opportunities for sunset hikes. The extended daylight hours mean you can start your ascent around 6 PM and still have plenty of time to reach the summit before golden hour.

Winter (Dec-Feb)

Best Times: 8 AM - 4 PM

Weather: Cool mornings, mild days

Highlights: Clear views, fewer crowds, crisp air. Pack layers as temperature can vary significantly between start and summit.

Spring (Mar-May)

Best Times: 7 AM - 6 PM

Weather: Perfect temperatures

Highlights: Wildflowers bloom, moderate crowds, ideal photography conditions. This is peak season for good reason.

Summer (Jun-Aug)

Best Times: Before 8 AM or after 6 PM

Weather: Hot, minimal shade

Highlights: Extended daylight for sunset hikes, but requires early starts to avoid heat. Bring extra water and sun protection.

Fall (Sep-Nov)

Best Times: 7 AM - 5 PM

Weather: Perfect hiking conditions

Highlights: Ideal temperatures, autumn light for photography, comfortable all-day hiking. My personal favorite season for this trail.

Weather conditions significantly impact your Mt Hollywood trail experience. I've hiked this trail in everything from clear Santa Ana wind conditions (offering incredible visibility to Catalina Island) to post-rain days when waterfalls temporarily appear on surrounding hillsides. The most challenging conditions I've encountered were during high wind events, which can make the exposed summit uncomfortable and potentially unsafe for inexperienced hikers.

For those interested in similar experiences throughout LA's hiking scene, I highly recommend exploring other trails that offer comparable views with different perspectives. The Manitou Incline provides a more challenging alternative, while trails throughout Angeles National Forest offer wilderness experiences beyond the urban hiking that characterizes Griffith Park.

Safety Tips and Trail Etiquette

While the Mt Hollywood trail is considered one of LA's safer hiking destinations, maintaining proper safety awareness ensures an enjoyable experience for everyone. Through my extensive time on this trail, I've observed patterns that can help both new and experienced hikers stay safe and comfortable.

The most significant safety consideration isn't wildlife or terrainâ€”it's other trail users. This trail's popularity means you'll encounter runners, dog walkers, families with children, and photographers, sometimes all simultaneously. I've learned to maintain heightened awareness, particularly on the wider fire road sections where mountain bikers occasionally venture despite regulations. Always hiking with proper supportive footwear has prevented several potential ankle injuries on uneven surfaces.

Wildlife encounters, while less common than on more remote trails, do occur. I've spotted coyotes twice during early morning hikes, both times at a respectful distance. The key is making noise and traveling in groups when possible. More commonly, you'll encounter various bird species and occasionally deer, particularly near Dante's View where the maintained vegetation attracts wildlife. rattlesnakes are present in the area, though I've only seen one in three years of regular hiking. Staying on designated trails and watching where you step or sit provides adequate protection.

Essential Safety Reminders:

  • Start early to avoid afternoon heat and crowds
  • Carry more water than you think you needâ€”minimum 32 oz per person
  • Inform someone of your hiking plans and expected return time
  • Stay on designated trails to prevent erosion and protect vegetation
  • Keep dogs leashed at all timesâ€”it's required and courteous
  • Pack out all trash, including organic waste like fruit peels

Trail etiquette on the Mt Hollywood trail follows standard hiking protocols, but the high traffic volume makes consideration especially important. Uphill hikers have the right of way, though I often step aside regardless of direction to allow faster-moving trail runners to pass safely. Photography is popular here, but I've noticed some visitors blocking paths or venturing off-trail for shots. Patience and communication usually resolve any conflicts.

Emergency preparedness on this trail differs from remote hiking situations due to excellent cell coverage and relatively quick access for emergency responders. However, I still recommend basic first aid knowledge and supplies, particularly for minor scrapes or sprains that could occur on the rockier sections. The proximity to Griffith Observatory means help is never far away, but self-sufficiency remains important.

Weather-related safety considerations vary significantly by season. Summer's heat poses the greatest risk, with dehydration and heat exhaustion possible for unprepared hikers. I've assisted several people who underestimated the intensity of Southern California sun at elevation. Winter hiking presents different challenges, primarily related to sudden weather changes and slippery conditions during the rare rain events.

Community User Reviews:

Sarah from Reddit: "The trail is well-maintained but can get dusty. Bring a bandana or buff for dusty conditions, especially if you're sensitive to particles in the air."

Mike from Amazon Review: "Parking is the biggest challenge. Arrive early or use the free Greek Theatre parking and walk upâ€”adds distance but saves money and stress."

Jennifer from Quora: "Best family hike in LA if you start early. My kids (ages 8 and 10) handled it fine with proper preparation and snacks."

Conclusion

After three years and countless hikes on the Mt Hollywood trail, I can confidently recommend this as Los Angeles' most accessible world-class hiking experience. This trail perfectly balances challenge with accessibility, offering genuine rewards for minimal technical difficulty. Whether you're a seasoned hiker seeking a quick workout with spectacular views or a visitor wanting to experience LA from a unique perspective, this trail delivers consistently.

The trail's greatest strength lies in its versatility. I've used it for solo contemplation during stressful periods, photography expeditions during golden hour, family outings with visiting relatives, and social hikes with fellow outdoor enthusiasts. Each experience revealed new aspects of both the trail and the city below. The seasonal changes, from spring wildflowers to winter's crystal-clear air, ensure that regular visitors never experience exactly the same hike twice.

For those planning their first visit, remember that preparation enhances enjoyment. Invest in quality hiking footwear, arrive early to secure parking and avoid crowds, bring more water than seems necessary, and allow extra time at the summit. The views deserve unhurried appreciation, and the descent often reveals perspectives missed during the focused ascent.

Ready to Experience Mt Hollywood Trail?

Start your adventure with proper preparation and quality gear

Get Premium Trekking Poles - $39.90

The Mt Hollywood trail represents what makes Los Angeles hiking special: world-class natural beauty accessible within one of America's largest urban areas. As development continues throughout Southern California, preserving and properly enjoying spaces like Griffith Park becomes increasingly important. This trail offers a perfect introduction to LA's extensive hiking culture while providing experiences that satisfy even veteran outdoor enthusiasts.

Whether you complete this hike once as a bucket list item or adopt it as a regular ritual like I have, the Mt Hollywood trail will likely exceed your expectations. Pack your water, lace up your boots, and prepare for some of the finest urban hiking in America. The city views are spectacular, but the sense of escape and accomplishment you'll gain from this accessible adventure might surprise you even more.

Frequently Asked Questions

How difficult is the Mt Hollywood trail for beginners?

The Mt Hollywood trail is perfect for beginners who want a rewarding hiking experience without technical challenges. The 2.5-mile round trip distance includes a manageable 500-foot elevation gain spread over wide, well-maintained paths. Most beginners can complete this hike in 1.5-2 hours, including time for photos and rest stops at scenic viewpoints. The trail's gradual incline and multiple rest areas make it accessible for various fitness levels. I recommend starting early in the morning to avoid crowds and heat, bringing plenty of water, and wearing supportive hiking shoes. The trail's popularity means you'll encounter other hikers who can offer assistance if needed, creating a safe environment for those new to hiking in Los Angeles.

What is the best time of day to hike Mt Hollywood trail?

The optimal times for hiking the Mt Hollywood trail are early morning (sunrise to 9 AM) and late afternoon (2 hours before sunset). Early morning offers cooler temperatures, fewer crowds, clearer air quality, and stunning sunrise opportunities from the summit. Late afternoon provides golden hour photography conditions and spectacular sunset views over the Pacific Ocean on clear days. During summer months, I strongly recommend morning hikes starting before 8 AM to avoid intense heat, as the trail offers minimal shade beyond the initial tree coverage. Winter allows more flexibility with comfortable hiking conditions throughout the day. Weekday mornings are significantly less crowded than weekends, providing a more peaceful experience for contemplation and photography.

Where can I park for the Mt Hollywood trail hike?

The main parking area is at Griffith Observatory, but availability varies dramatically by time and day. The observatory charges $4-15 per hour depending on the season and demand. Free parking alternatives include the Greek Theatre area (adding about 0.5 miles each way to your hike) and spots along Los Feliz Boulevard, though these require longer walks to the trailhead. For guaranteed parking, arrive before 8 AM on weekdays or consider taking the DASH Observatory shuttle bus from the Vermont/Sunset Metro station. Weekend parking fills quickly, especially during peak seasons and special events. I've found that the most stress-free approach involves planning to arrive at the trailhead very early or budgeting for paid parking as part of the hiking experience.

Can I bring my dog on the Mt Hollywood trail?

Dogs are welcome on the Mt Hollywood trail but must remain leashed at all times according to Griffith Park regulations. The trail is very dog-friendly with several water sources, including a fountain at Dante's View where dogs can drink. Consider your dog's fitness level, as the 2.5-mile distance with elevation gain can be challenging for some pets, especially in hot weather. Bring extra water for your dog, check paw pads regularly on hot pavement near the trailhead, and be prepared to clean up after your pet. The trail's popularity means you'll encounter many other dogs, so ensure your pet is comfortable with social situations. Summer hiking requires special caution for dogs due to hot surfaces and limited shade, making early morning starts essential for their safety and comfort.

What should I bring for hiking Mt Hollywood trail?

Essential items for the Mt Hollywood trail include at least 32 ounces of water per person (more in summer), sunscreen, snacks for energy, and comfortable hiking shoes with good traction. A hat and sunglasses provide crucial sun protection on the exposed sections. I recommend bringing a camera for the spectacular views, a small first aid kit for minor scrapes, and layers for changing weather conditions. Trekking poles can help with stability, though they're not required for this moderately challenging trail. Cell phone service is excellent throughout the hike, but download offline maps as backup. Consider bringing a headlamp for early morning or evening hikes, and always pack out all trash to preserve this beautiful area for future visitors. Quality gear enhances safety and enjoyment significantly.

How long does it take to complete the Mt Hollywood trail?

Most hikers complete the Mt Hollywood trail in 1.5 to 2 hours, including stops for photos and rest at scenic viewpoints. The actual hiking time averages 45-60 minutes each direction for moderately fit individuals, but the summit views deserve extended appreciation time. Factors affecting duration include fitness level, weather conditions, crowd size, and photography interests. Early morning hikes typically move faster due to fewer people and cooler temperatures. Allow extra time during peak seasons when the trail becomes crowded, potentially slowing progress at narrow sections. Sunset hikes require careful timing to ensure safe descent in diminishing light. I recommend planning 2.5-3 hours total for a relaxed experience that includes time to enjoy the incredible panoramic views that make this trail one of Los Angeles' most rewarding short hikes.
